WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- President Bush sent lawmakers a $2.57 trillion, fiscal 2006 spending plan that aims to stem a flow of government red ink by clamping down on non-military, domestic spending.
 
 The blue-and-tan budget tome outlines Bush's effort to cut or eliminate some 150 federal spending programs, while holding overall discretionary spending -- outlays set by Congress each year -- to an increase of 2.1 percent, lower than the rate of inflation.
 
 Defense spending would rise by 4.8 percent, while non-security discretionary spending would fall by nearly 1 percent in fiscal 2006, which begins Oct. 1.
